I will refrain from using the word 'God' because its much like saying "I drive a 'car". It is a generic reference to something that some of us believe may exist.
 
 This topic concerns a key point I made in a discussion with a Deist. He claimed that physical cosmology provides evidence for the Divine in the Big Bang theory which theorizes the universe had a beginning. He then went on to say that because there was a beginning, the universe was finite, therefore, there was a Creator. I simply pointed out that there is no conclusive evidence supporting the notion that a beginning equates to finiteness, and the universe very well could be infinite. I think that busted the hole in his argument. I don't think there is any scientific evidence for or against the Divine, yet. The best that science will be able to do is show that the Divine is necessary or unnecessary.

 That which is material, substantial, and corporeal has by definition, the quality of 'extension'. That is, it can be measured in terms of place, occupied space [physical dimensions], and time. Anything which can be measured wrt 'extension' is finite, because extension is a limiting quality. Anything 'infinite' cannot have 'extension', because extension is expressed in terms of its limits, its, 'finiteness'. And it should be noted that extension is always relative, as well.
 
 Now anything that has a beginning had a beginning to its own 'extension', and by definition anything with a beginning has extension which doesa not proceed indefinitel into the past, but stops at that beginning. Therefore anything with a beginning is by definition limited in terms of its past, and so cannot be infinite, wrt time, although theoretically it might be everlasting. But no matter how long it lasts, it will always be temporal, not eternal, simply because it had a beginning.
 
 Now a corporeal, substantial, physical entity cannot be said to exist unless it can be identified, and it can only be identified by its dimensions, that is, its form, as that form conforms to the quality of extension. Size, shape, weight, etc. That is, those properties accessible to our five senses and where necessary, our tools. If only one homogenous entity experienced a beginning, but was somehow sentient, it would know that it had a beginning, but it would know nothing else, because it would have nothing else to compare itself to. It would be neither finite nor infinite, so far as it could tell. But it two or more entities have beginnings, then, provided they are sentient, they could see, relative to one another, the boundaries of physical existence in terms of 'place', making that 'place' [eg., our universe] finite. That place would be confined, and therefore defined as the space 'extension' that contains corporeal entities that can be themselves defined in terms of extension as individuals with measurable properties that are comparable, hence relative.
 By definition these physical properties cannot be infinite, because if they were they would blend together in one single, indistinguishable, indefinite, corporeal, substantial, material mass in which they occupied the whole of everything that is. But we can see that that is not the case. Corporeal, physical entities are distinguishable from one another, and by that token alone they are finite, and the space they occupy, i.e., this corporeal universe, is finite. And solely because these things are finite, we can observe and measure them, time, space, velocity, and whatnot.
 
 Your opponent is right. That which has a beginning, and all that is physical,(and all that which is this corporeal universe had a beginning), is by definition, limited in terms of extension, hence finite.
 
 WRT "the divine", that which has a beginning could not poof itself into existence at its beginning, but had to be an effect produced by some other agency. Ex nihilo, nihil fit. For the same reason an effect cannot be greater than its own cause. Therefore the agency that generated this corporeal, physical universe is greater than this universe. How much greater is impossible to say with certainty, but if it is finite then it had a beginning and had to come out of something greater than itself, and on and on in infinite regression, making a mockery of limits, including the measurable limits science studies and measures in our world. Measurement and extension are rendered absurd. Therefore regression cannot be indefinite, and whatever agency generated a universe limited by 'extension' cannot suffer from the same limitation. But whether the agency that generated the limitations of our world, albeit free of those limitations, is in all other ways just as unlimited, i.e., is infinite in all respects, simply cannot be assumed. Because if it were infinite, it would, by definition, be perfect, because it would be all that it could be. It could not change, since to change perfection is to create imperfection. And because it could not change, it could not compare, and without comparison there is no identification, and without identification there is no knowledge, and no self-awareness. Therefore, contra most religious traditions, that which is the source of the physical universe, albeit vastly greater than the universe, cannot be limitless/infinite, and cannot be perfect, or it would never have begun the universe that we know.
 
 The paradox in all this is that an imperfect 'divinity', one limited enough to be capable of change and creation, is truly more perfect than a perfect than one that is infinite, hence 'perfect', hence incapable of change, creation, or even self-awareness. Also, one that cannot make anything possible, but establishes its own limits, so that there are only some things it can do, and others that it cannot, in order to imbue that which it can do with law, order, and reason.

Science can disprove individual theologies, whenever they make claims that are testable. Young Earth Creationism, for example, claims that Noah's Ark was real, but the scientific evidence has disproved that notion -- there was no single world-wide flood. That doesn't mean the legend of Noah didn't have some truth somewhere in it, but if so, it wasn't the global deluge claimed by Creationists. that's plain naive. Actually, it's stupid. So science has disproved Noah theology.
 
 Still, there are limits to what science can prove or disprove. It can't prove or disprove a creator, an originator of the universe, at least, not at present. It can't prove or disprove claims such as the notion that the universe was created with the appearance of evolution. It can't prove or disprove the notion that the universe was created last Tuesday, with all of us, our personal histories and memories intact, de novo. 
 
 There are lots of religious claims that science can't touch, but that doesn't mean it is reasonable to believe them. We don't live in a world where if science can't explain it, the magical mystery man's version must be right. There are lots of magical mystery men... some preach Jesus, others preach some other god. If science can't explain it, all we can truthfully say is "we don't know".

Sometimes its useful to trace the history of ideas and concepts. This is true of the "vital force" please consider the bit from Wiki below.
 
 ==================================
 
 
 Élan vital
 From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
 Jump to: navigation, search
 
 For other meanings, see Elan Vital
 
 Élan vital, coined by French philosopher Henri Bergson in his 1907 book Creative Evolution, was translated in the English edition as "vital impetus", but is usually translated by his detractors as "vital force". It is a hypothetical explanation for evolution and development of organisms, which Bergson linked closely with consciousness.
 
 It was believed by others that this essence (élan vital) could be harvested and embedded into an inanimate substance and activated with electricity, perhaps taking literally another of Bergson's metaphorical descriptions, the "current of life". The British biologist Julian Huxley remarked that Bergson's élan vital is no better an explanation of life than is explaining the operation of a railway engine by élan locomotif. However, Huxley himself subscribed to the notion of an élan vital as may be seen from the following excerpt: "When I was last in New York, I went for a walk, leaving Fifth Avenue and the Business section behind me, into the crowded streets near the Bowery. And while I was there, I had a sudden feeling of relief and confidence. There was Bergson's élan vital - there was assimilation causing life to exert as much pressure, though embodied here in the shape of men, as it has ever done in the earliest year of evolution: - there was the driving force of progress" (lecture 1, n.p., J. Huxley Papers).
 
 A distant precursor of Bergson can be found in the work of the pre-Christian Stoic philosopher Posidonius, who postulated a "vital force" emanated by the sun to all living creatures on the earth's surface. The concept of élan vital is very similar to Schopenhauer's concept of the will-to-live. Several other ideas throughout Bergson's works are reminiscent of Schopenhauer's thoughts.
 
 The French philosopher Gilles Deleuze attempted to recoup the novelty of Bergson's idea in his book Bergsonism, though the term itself underwent substantial changes by Deleuze. No longer considered a mystical, elusive force acting on brute matter, as it was in the vitalist debates of the late 19th century, élan vital in Deleuze's hands denotes a substance in which the distinction between organic and inorganic matter is indiscernible, and the emergence of life undecidable.
 ========================================

 Your argument is specious. Many organisms are composed of more than one cell. Each and every cell, everywhere, is either alive or dead. There is no law, and there needs be no law, that organisms composed of multiple cells, even billions of cells, must have each and evewry one of those cells die at the very same instant, otherwise the qualitative distinction between 'life' and 'death' is 'blurred'. That's simply irrational. The distinction between a live multi-celled organism and a dead one may appear 'blurred' and continuous because not all of its billions of cells die at the exact same instant, but that not where life and death reside at the qualitative level, as opposed to your emphasis on the collective, organismic, quantitative level. At the qualitative level, life and death are distinguished at the cellular level, and even there there is no law saying that the transition from life to death need be total and instantaneous. Just so long as truly dead is empirically distinguishable from truly alive, all your little monty python jokes count for nothing.
chemist99a

At the qualitative level, life and death are distinguished at the cellular level, and even there there is no law saying that the transition from life to death need be total and instantaneous. Just so long as truly dead is empirically distinguishable from truly alive, all your little monty python jokes count for nothing.
 Cells exhibit a continuium between what we would call life and what we would call death. As you say death is not instantaneous, therefore its not a threshold effect and the transition is blurry. Subcellular processes wind down gradually you know not all at once. A single cell is at its own scale self-similar to multicellular organisms. Think fractals. And bear in mind I am not arguing that we cannot classify an organism or a cell as being dead or alive, all I am saying is that the borderline is fuzzy rather than brightline. And that very fact means that its difficult to assign somthing like a virus as being dead or alive. If you declare a virus dead then its hard to see how it can reproduce and grow etc. If you declare it alive its difficult to see how it can be so without an internal metabolic system. Its my contention that there is no bright-line border which distinguishes matter into two types - living and non-living. The border is fuzzy. Thus its not necessary to have life simply appear, all thats needed is for chemical complexity to increase until it has clearly crossed the fuzzy borderline. So you get non-living matter, more complex non-living matter, still more complex non-living matter, not quite non-living matter, nearly living-matter, more nearly-living matter, and just barely living matter, then clearly living matter, and then complex living matter. In other words the non-living grades into the living and bright line abiogenesis is not the issue. The issue is whether or not matter has the inherent potential to be organized into sufficiently complex structures so as to become living. The observation that we do in fact have life is sufficient to conclude that it does. No external agency is required, no external agency need be invoked to explain it.

In other words, the root of belief is probably a vestigial evolutionary adaptation of cognitive behavior which enhanced social cohesiveness, (undoubtedly a bonus early on), and it is a state of mind which is nurtured with the best reason available to it, even if that reason was bad. Belief can be a partner to good reason as well as bad.
